thread.title: 'Extraordinary numbers' of mosquitoes give way to record Ross River Virus season in NSW
thread.title_full: 'Extraordinary numbers' of mosquitoes give way to record Ross River Virus season in NSW

author: Harriet Alexander
title: 'Extraordinary numbers' of mosquitoes give way to record Ross River Virus season in NSW
text:
'Extraordinary numbers' of mosquitoes give way to record Ross River Virus season in NSW Harriet Alexander twitter TWEET More 
Scientists believe NSW may be coming to the end of the biggest season for Ross River Virus in living memory, after inland flooding in spring created the perfect breeding conditions for mosquitoes that carry the disease. 
More than five times as many people contracted the virus in December and January than did over the same period last year, with 560 notifications compared to 96 last year. In the first six weeks of this year alone 430 people have been affected. How to avoid Ross River virus How to avoid Ross River virus 
Sydney pathologist Cameron Webb explains what Ross River fever is, the symptoms to watch for and how to avoid Australia's most significant mosquito-borne disease. Up Next Redback spider vs snake Redback spider vs snake 
Brenton Marr tells 3AW this incredible footage of a spider killing a snake was shot at his engine shop in northern Victoria, where "we breed our spiders tough". Up Next Hackett claims he was bashed Play Video Hackett claims he was bashed 
Grant Hackett alleges his brother bashed him while posting a photo on Instagram. Up Next Grant Hackett in police custody Play Video Grant Hackett in police custody Grant Hackett in police custody 
Former Olympic swimmer Grant Hackett's brother has said he no longer knows the person his brother has become. Vision courtesy: Nine News Up Next PM has the final say Play Video PM has the final say 
Malcolm Turnbull has made his views clear on whether there'll be company tax concessions. Up Next Family's plea to help Hackett Play Video Family's plea to help Hackett Family's plea to help Hackett 
The family of Grant Hackett described the Olympic swimming great as "dangerousâ" and in desperate need of help after his arrest at his parent's Gold Coast home. Courtesy Seven Network Up Next Hey big spender Hey big spender 
Peter Dutton's Immigration department has put forward a proposal to spend more than $250 million fitting out its Canberra offices. Up Next More videos How to avoid Ross River virus 
Sydney pathologist Cameron Webb explains what Ross River fever is, the symptoms to watch for and how to avoid Australia's most significant mosquito-borne disease. 
The virus causes fever, headaches, chills and stiffness in the muscles in joints, and though it usually resolves within 10 days some patients experience symptoms for months. 
The NSW opposition has called on the government to consider targeted spraying of areas in which those mosquitoes breed, including the tidal areas of the Georges River, Parramatta River and Hawkesbury River. SHARE Aedes vigilax. Credit Stephen Doggett (NSW Health Pathology) Photo: Aedes vigilax. Credit Stephen Do 
The Riverina area, particularly the towns of Albury and Griffith, has been hardest hit, but cases have also been identified in the Hunter-New England and suburbs around the Georges River, including Alfreds Point, Lugarno and Illawong. 
NSW Health Pathology senior scientist Stephen Doggett said heavy flooding in the early part of the season had given rise to a huge number of mosquitoes across the inland regions, and a substantial increase in Ross River Virus notifications had been noted from November. Advertisement 
"We've seen a massive amount of mosquitoes - probably the highest we've ever seen," Mr Doggett said. 
"Extraordinary numbers. And we've seen a massive increase in reports of Ross River Virus through the months of December and January. SHARE Senior Hospital Scientist at Westmead Hospital Stephen Doggett Photo: Wolter Peeters 
"They were many, many times higher than our previous records and we've been doing this work since the late 80s. 
"Now because we've had this hot dry weather mosquito numbers are dropping off and we're starting to see a bit of a decline in cases, but still last week there were 82 cases which is more than double the month's average in one week. It appears that the virus has exploded and now it's burnt itself out." SHARE Opposition health spokesman Walt Secord, left, with opposition leader Luke Foley. Photo: Jane Dyson 
Opposition health spokesman Walt Secord said the Health Minister Brad Hazzard should step up education campaigns to prevent mosquito-borne illnesses. 
"NSW is in the grip of a serious Ross River Fever outbreak," Mr Secord said. 
"It is a preventable illness and we want the state government to consider undertaking targeting spraying and other preventative measures." 
The virus is mostly confined to the west of the Great Dividing Range where saltmarsh mosquitoes breed, but it has also been detected in today river areas such as the Georges River and Parramatta River. 
However, the disease is believed to be spread by mosquitoes that have bitten wallabies and kangaroos that carry the disease, so it is less prevalent in urban environments where there are fewer marsupial carriers. 
Mr Doggett said he supported targeted spraying of mosquito larvae in areas where the disease was prevalent, but the cost of $5000 per treatment was prohibitive for regional councils. The total bill could climb to $30,000 for a season, he said. 
"As a mosquito person I would say, yes, undertaking larval control would reduce the disease burden, but when you go to inland NSW you're talking about huge, huge hectares and huge cost and this is why it gets difficult." 
NSW Health advises people to protect themselves against infection by wearing long-sleeved clothes and insect repellent and using netting, mosquito coils and plug-in devices. 
Mr Hazzard has been contacted for comment. Advertisement Most Popular
